payload.name: rhetorical
payload.core: Reasoning aimed at belief-change and coordinated action through audience-aware communication. Applies the classical triad: ethos (speaker credibility), pathos (emotional resonance), logos (logical structure). Key constraint: adoption-oriented but truth-anchored; persuasion must not compromise accuracy.

out.d: claims sequenced for audience acceptance; format: claim + warrant + evidence + call-to-action
explicit mapping of issue to audience values; format: value | connection | message angle
documented weighting of ethos/pathos/logos with justification for context
anticipated objections with pre-crafted responses; columns: objection | source | response | evidence
channel, timing, messenger selection; includes feedback loops

proc: 1. profile audience: list stakeholders, their values (ranked), concerns, prior beliefs, trust level with speaker
2. truth-anchor: enumerate factual claims to be made; verify each independently before proceeding
3. select framing: choose 2-3 candidate frames; score each on (a) audience resonance, (b) accuracy preservation, (c) action clarity

4. calibrate appeal mix: if audience skeptical of speaker -> emphasize logos + third-party ethos; if audience analytically oriented -> lead with logos; if audience faces decision fatigue -> simplify to single clear ask with pathos hook
5. construct argument arc: opening hook (pathos or ethos) -> problem framing -> evidence (logos) -> vision (pathos) -> ask (logos)
6. objection mapping: list top 3 objections by likelihood; prepare response for each with evidence
7. integrity check: would you deliver this message if the audience had full context? if no, revise
8. channel-fit: match message length/complexity to medium (email < deck < whitepaper < conversation)

pre_delivery: all factual claims verified with citations
framing does not omit material counter-evidence
audience profile based on evidence, not assumption
fallback position prepared if primary ask rejected
post_delivery: collect audience feedback on perceived honesty
track whether commitments made during persuasion are kept
note which appeals landed vs fell flat for iteration

check: audience profile includes evidence sources (not just intuition)
every emotional appeal paired with factual grounding
framing passes reversal test: would opponent call it fair?
no claims that require hiding contrary evidence
message unchanged if delivered to hostile fact-checker
long-term relationship value exceeds short-term win value

diff.argumentation-theory: rhetoric optimizes for adoption; argumentation optimizes for logical defensibility regardless of audience
diff.theory-of-mind: ToM builds mental model of audience; rhetoric applies that model to craft persuasive message
diff.narrative: narrative explains causally (what happened and why); rhetoric persuades (what to believe or do)
diff.dialectical: dialectic seeks synthesis through opposition; rhetoric seeks adoption of a position
diff.negotiation: negotiation trades value between parties; rhetoric changes beliefs without exchange
diff.deductive: deduction preserves truth through inference; rhetoric preserves truth while optimizing uptake

common_confusions.confusion: both involve argumentation, so seem similar
common_confusions.distinction: dialectic progresses thesis->antithesis->synthesis seeking truth; rhetoric advocates for a position seeking adoption. Dialectic welcomes opposition; rhetoric anticipates and neutralizes it.

narrative mode constructs causal explanations (postmortems, strategy rationales); rhetorical mode uses story elements instrumentally for persuasion. Narrative asks 'what happened?'; rhetoric asks 'how do I get them to act?'

common_confusions.confusion: both aim to change outcomes with others
common_confusions.distinction: negotiation involves mutual concession and value exchange; rhetoric is unilateral belief/action change. Negotiation requires something to trade; rhetoric requires only communication.

signals: factual claims not independently verified before use
counter-evidence known but omitted from framing
emotional appeals disconnected from factual basis
audience modeled as marks rather than partners
message would change if audience had full context

mitigations.test: can you cite source for each factual claim?
mitigations.action: add citation or mark as uncertain; do not present uncertain claims as fact

mitigations.test: list 3 strongest objections; is any based on evidence you're hiding?
mitigations.action: if yes, either address the evidence explicitly or revise the claim

mitigations.test: remove pathos from argument; does logos still support the ask?
mitigations.action: if logos alone is insufficient, strengthen evidence before adding pathos back

mitigations.test: would you publish this framing in a transparency report?
mitigations.action: if no, reframe to pass the transparency test

mitigations.test: would the message hold if delivered to a skeptical journalist?
mitigations.action: if no, revise until it passes adversarial review

use: change management: building buy-in for organizational shifts
stakeholder alignment: creating shared understanding across groups
executive communication: presenting recommendations to decision-makers
policy advocacy: influencing policy through structured argument
product positioning: framing offerings relative to alternatives
crisis communication: maintaining trust while delivering difficult news

rel.r: provides logical structure that rhetoric makes persuasive
supplies audience model that rhetoric operationalizes
provides causal stories that rhetoric employs for persuasion
opposition mode; use dialectic to refine position, then rhetoric to advocate
when belief-change insufficient, escalate to value exchange

ex.sit: Engineering team must convince leadership to invest in technical debt reduction. Leadership values speed and features.
steps: 1. audience profile: CFO (ROI-focused, skeptical of eng requests), CTO (understands debt, politically constrained), CEO (speed-obsessed, trusts metrics)
2. truth-anchor: verify claims - defect rate up 40% YoY, feature velocity down 25%, competitor shipped 2x features

3. framing candidates: (a) 'cleanup' - low resonance, sounds like housekeeping; (b) 'velocity tax' - moderate, implies ongoing cost; (c) 'competitive catch-up' - high resonance, connects to CEO priority
4. appeal mix: CEO is metrics-oriented -> lead with logos (velocity data), add pathos (competitive threat vision)
5. argument arc: hook (competitor momentum) -> problem (velocity declining) -> evidence (metrics) -> vision (Q3 parity) -> ask (6-week sprint)
6. objection matrix: 'delays roadmap' -> show roadmap acceleration post-investment; 'unproven ROI' -> cite prior debt sprint results
7. integrity check: message holds under full disclosure; not hiding positive competitor factors
8. channel: 30-min exec briefing with 5-slide deck; pre-wire CTO for support
ex.insight: reframing technical debt as competitive velocity unlocked exec sponsorship by connecting engineering need to business priority

micro_ex.sit: Convince team to adopt code review checklist
micro_ex.appeal_mix: ethos (senior engineer endorsement) + logos (defect data from pilot) + pathos (pride in quality)
micro_ex.message: Our pilot cut review-found bugs by 30%. Senior devs already use it. Let's make quality our signature.
micro_ex.why_it_works: combines credibility (senior endorsement), evidence (30% reduction), and identity appeal (quality as team identity)
